awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Algorithmic Techniques for High-throughput Analysis of Long Reads
awd_abstract_narration:
The field of DNA sequencing has rapidly evolved from Sanger sequencing (700-1000 base pairs, or bp, in length) to massively parallel high-throughput sequencing of short reads (100-200 bp) to the more recent advances in generating long (> 5,000 bp) and ultra-long (> 50,000 bp) reads. There is currently an urgent need to develop efficient algorithms for analyzing long-read datasets in the context of the myriad biological applications they enable. Long read technologies sustain high error rates but with more attractive error distribution characteristics that often permit probabilistic guarantees on the quality of results. This project will result in fundamental research advances in developing bioinformatics algorithms for long-read sequencing, along with distributable open-source software products to facilitate their immediate adoption by the life sciences community. The award will also support interdisciplinary training, and undergraduate participation in research.

The project seeks to advance mapping, assembly, and biological applications of long-read sequencing through the design of provably efficient algorithms, formal characterization of the quality of results, development of methods that scale to larger datasets, and methods that are robust to changes brought about by continued developments in long read sequencing. Problems addressed include (i) split-read mapping of ultra-long reads to a reference genome, (ii) development of data structures based on bloom filters to achieve space optimization and perfect statistical sensitivity, (iii) algorithms for mapping long reads to a collection of reference genomes represented by compact graph-based structures, (iv) algorithms for partitioning long reads to facilitate identification of haplotypes in diploid assemblies, and (v) long-read inspired alignment free algorithms for genome-to-genome comparison, as well as important biological applications enabled by these. The research will emphasize utilization of real datasets, relevance to practically encountered problems and applications, and independent validation by collaborators and other experts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project investigated algorithms for analyzing long DNA sequencing data. It also analyzed other bioinformatics problems and applications that can be solved by mathematical techniques developed for long read analysis. In addition, the project considered how genetic variations among numerous individuals in a population can be succinctly represented using genome graphs, and how such graphs can be used as a reference to map DNA sequences from another individual.

Intellectual Merits: The project advanced both fundamental and applied research in this emerging area along all the directions mentioned above. We developed the first long read mapping technique that scales to entire genetic databases, and in addition used such techniques to compare sequences within the human genome to identify all segmental duplications. We developed techniques for nanopore long read mapping directly in the signal space, avoiding the need to convert signals to DNA bases to enable faster discovery of whether the DNA being sequenced is useful, so that it can be ejected from the instrumentation on the fly.

Utilizing techniques developed for long read mapping, we developed a novel method to estimate the average nucleotide level similarity between two microbial genomes. Our method is correctly able to identify when two microbial genomes belong to the same species or not in 99.79% of the cases, based on an analysis of all known microbial genomes. This provides a data-driven answer to the century old question: do microbial species exist, or is there continuity along the genetic spectrum because of their unique ability to exchange genes without sexual reproduction? This work is heavily cited and is generating a robust discussion among the scientific community.

In the genome graph area, we developed the first and comprehensive mathematical framework to determine which genetic variations among the population should be included in creating a population reference. A surprising result is that a mathematical approach to this problem guarantees subsequent accuracy in mapping DNA sequences, without having to take into account the biological importance of the individual variations. We solved eight different problems resulting from this mathematical framework. In sequence to graph mapping, we were the first to characterize the difficulty of solving the problem for DNA or protein sequences, and  for commonly used bioinformatics data structures such as de Bruijn graphs. We also developed several practical algorithms for carrying out sequence to graph mapping.

Broader Impacts: The algorithms developed under this project are made available as open source software packages under GitHub that allow wide use and adaptation. Six software packages were developed, one which is itself a software suite consisting of five software products. Two of the software packages deserve special mention. FastANI, the algorithm we developed for microbial sequence comparison, is downloaded more than 44,500 times as of this writing. The MashMap2 software for aligning long reads is downloaded more than 13,000 times as of this writing.

The project enabled human resource development in an important interdisciplinary research area, to support working on important emerging topics. Three Ph.D. dissertations resulted from the work supported on this project, and it also supported the training of a postdoctoral research associate.
